lines.text: Why, I can smile... And murder while I smile!

[to the Duke of Buckingham]
I am not in the giving vein today.
No beast so fierce but knows some touch of pity.
But I know none, and therefore am no beast.
I have no more sons of the royal blood for you to slaughter.
You have a daughter.

[to the camera]
I'll have her, but I'll not keep her long.

[to the camera]
I am not made of stone.
A horse! A horse! My kingdom for a horse!
Are you my son?
Yes. I thank God, my father, and yourself.
Now is the winter of our discontent made glorious summer by this sun of York.

[to the camera]
Plots have I laid.
Madam, mother, I do humbly crave your blessing.
God comfort you; and put meekness in your breast, love, charity, obedience and true duty!
Amen;
[aside]
and make me die a good old man! That is the butt-end of a mother's blessing.

[to the Duke of Buckingham]
Shall I be plain? I wish the bastards dead.
Shall I be tempted by the devil thus?
Yes, if the devil tempt you to do good.

[to Richard III]
Tell me, thou villain slave!
[screams]
Where are my children?
No doubt the murderous knife was dull before it was whetted on your stone-hard heart.
But you did kill my children.
Where, in that nest of spicery, they will breed.
[his last words]
Made I him king for this?
[Tyrell garrotes him]
Conscience is but a word cowards use.
My Lord protector, what should we do if we perceive Hastings will not yield to our plans?
Chop off his head.
[first lines]
Goodnight Father.
Goodnight son.
Goodnight your majesty.
I will send you to my brother Richard, who shall reward you better for my life than will the King for tidings of my death.
You are deceived. Your brother Richard hates you.
Go you to him. Tell him that, he will weep.
If she hath done this deed, my lord...
If! Thou protector of this damned strumpet, talk'st thou to me of if? Thou art a traitor! Off with his head. By St Paul I shall not dine until I see the same. Those who love me stand and follow me!

[to Hastings]
His grace would have dinner.
I shall not sleep in quiet at the tower.
Why? What should you fear?
My grandma told me he was murdered there.
I fear no Uncles dead.
Nor none who live, I hope.

[to Richard III]
You came on earth to make the earth my hell.

[to the camera]
Simple, plain Clarence! I do love you so, that I shall shortly send your soul to heaven. If heaven will take the present from my hands.
God grant we never may have need of you!
The King is sickly, weak and melancholy.
There's no doubt his Majesty will soon recover his accustom'd health.
But his physicians fear for him mightily. If he were dead, what would become of me?

[to Richard III]
Did you not kill my husband?

[to Lady Anne]
Your beauty which did haunt me in my sleep could make me undertake the death of all the world.
To whom in all this presence speaks your grace?
To you, who have neither honesty, nor Grace.
Edward, my Lord, your son, our King, is dead.
I see the ruin of my family.

[to Richard III]
Know then, it is your fault that you refuse the supreme seat, the throne majestical. We heartily solicit you take on the kingly government of this your land. Not as Lord protector, but from blood to blood, your right of birth, your empery, your own.
Long live, King Richard!

[to Richard III]
To war take with you my most gravest curse! My prayers shall on Richard's party fight. Bloody you are! Bloody will be your end! Shame serves your life and will your death attend.
[last lines]
Let us to't pell-mell, if not to heaven, then hand in hand to hell.
